docs.lead_paragraph: IT is midmorning on a Thursday and women in their teens and early 20's straggle in, one by one, to a conference room at Waterbury Hospital until there are seven of them, bound together in a common -- and obvious -- sisterhood: They're all pregnant. Each checks her weight on a scale (sometimes with a gasp of dismay), then her blood pressure with a small monitor and records the information from both on a form. Then they will settle back on chairs set in a semi-circle, to chat a bit with each other but mostly to listen a lot to Sharon Schindler Rising.

headline.main: Getting Ready for Baby With a Helping Hand; Five-Minute Doctor Visits Can Be Replaced With Midwife-Led Support Sessions

docs.abstract: Article on increase in midwifery in Connecticut and across US focuses on work of nurse-midwife Sharon Schindler Rising, who works at prenatal clinic at Waterbury Hospital; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For Allen Iverson, Philadelphia freedom once meant driving the length of the court, and then using the defense and his teammates for pylons. He would score spectacularly and often. But the 76ers would invariably drop another game, after which Iverson would shrug his shoulders and exclaim, ''What more do you want me to do?'' Now look who's all grown up.

headline.main: Iverson Learning It's Not All Ego

docs.lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, in movieland, couples met cute. In ''Relax . . . It's Only Sex,'' they have sex cute. Two fashionable West Hollywood gay men make love while discussing a future menu (something about salmon and fresh parsley). Another gay man carries on an internal (voice-over) monologue through much of the act about the advisability of taking a particular health risk. The film's token straight couple ravage each other in the kitchen so recklessly that nearby pots and pans rattle and clatter to the floor. This is shortly after the woman, Tara (Jennifer Tilly), tries to prove just how adorably frank she is by hitting the man, Gus (Timothy Paul Perez), on the back and whining, ''But I want your sperm!'' Tara sets the tone for ''Relax . . . It's Only Sex,'' an energetic and often good-looking but completely unseductive film from P. J. Castellaneta. In this comic drama about a group of California friends, Tara gets the lines that are meant to be endearingly naive (''AIDS is the biggest tragedy of the 20th century. Even Madonna thinks so.'') or casually clever (''You know how lesbians are. They're like Catholics or 'Saturday Night Live.' They go on forever, no matter how bad it gets'').

headline.main: The Names Are Quirky, and the Sex Is More So

docs.lead_paragraph: Justice Harry A. Blackmun, a modest Midwestern Republican who became a passionate defender of the right to abortion in 24 years on the Supreme Court, died today at the age of 90. Justice Blackmun, who retired from the Court five years ago, died of complications after hip replacement surgery, the Court announced. He underwent the procedure last week after a fall at his home in suburban Virginia.

headline.main: Justice Blackmun, Author of Abortion Right, Dies

docs.abstract: Justice Harry A Blackmun, modest Midwestern Republican who became passionate defender of right to abortion in 24 years on Supreme Court, dies at age of 90; he had retired from Court five years ago; despite active, 62-year career as lawyer and judge, his name is forever linked to issue of abortion and to opinion that bore his signature, Roe v Wade; he began his tenure on Supreme Court in 1970 as liflong Republican never known for breaking new ground or challenging status quo; by time of his retirement, he was one of last liberal voices on transformed Court; although vote in Roe v Wade was 7 to 2, it was Blackmun who became personal symbol of abortion issue that assumed increasingly dominant, and divisive, role in American politics; although Blackmun maintained that it was Court that changed, not he, evidence of his own evolution is unmistakable; one example is reversal of his long-held support of death penalty, having concluded after many years that capital punishment could not be carried out in manner consistent with Constitution; Harry Andrew Blackmun was born Nov 12, 1908; detailed profile of his life and career; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Justice Harry A. Blackmun, a modest Midwestern Republican who became a passionate defender of the right to abortion in 24 years on the Supreme Court, died today at the age of 90.    Justice Blackmun, who retired from the Court five years ago, died of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from opinions Justice Harry A. Blackmun wrote in his 24 years on the Supreme Court, including his opinion for the Court in the 1973 decision in Roe v. Wade finding a constitutional right to abortion: Roe v. Wade The Court has recognized that a right of personal privacy, or a guarantee of certain areas or zones of privacy, does exist under the Constitution. . . . This right of privacy, whether it be founded in the 14th Amendment's concept of personal liberty and restrictions upon state action, as we feel it is, or, as the District Court determined, in the Ninth Amendment's reservation of rights to the people, is broad enough to encompass a woman's decision whether or not to terminate her pregnancy.

headline.main: Blackmun's Opinions Reflect His Evolution Over the 24 Court Years

docs.lead_paragraph: The Nuveen Masters, the season-ending event to decide the champion of the men's senior circuit, has hit hard luck for the second year in a row. Last year its leading player, Jimmy Connors, withdrew from the championship with a respiratory problem. This week's $300,000 tournament in Naples, Fla., is unfolding without the circuit's new No. 1, John McEnroe, who was on a 20-match unbeaten streak and owned a tour-leading eight titles heading into the championship.
docs.abstract: John McEnroe withdraws from Nuveen Masters, season-ending event to decide champion of men's senior tennis circuit (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ten months ago when their baby girl, Grace, was born, Leon Wynter and his wife, Yvonne Parnell Wynter, finally ended -- or at least postponed -- an argument they had been having throughout the pregnancy: whether or not to circumcise a boy. ''When it came up, my wife said, 'No, I'm not going to let it happen,' '' said Mr. Wynter, a columnist for The Wall Street Journal and a journalism professor at Baruch College in New York City.
docs.abstract: American Academy of Pediatrics, which has had three different policies on circumcision in 30 years, now says data are 'not significant enough' to recommend routine circumcision; says, for first time, that if parents do circumcise son, relieving pain is essential, using numbing creams or injections that are found to be safe and effective; new report, which appears in March issue of journal Pediatrics, scrutinizes and partly discounts potential benefits of circumcision cited 10 years ago (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: They baptize people, confirm them, preach to them, marry them, bury them, and now, like it or not, in the face of AIDS, priests, ministers and other members of the clergy are teaching parishioners about sex. And nowhere is the need felt more urgently than in places black people worship, whether Roman Catholic, Pentecostal or Muslim.

headline.main: Slowly Breaking the Silence on AIDS

docs.abstract: Black churches are at last facing up to issue of AIDS, which they have been slow to do even though AIDS continues to pose disproportionate peril to blacks; religious leaders are increasingly speaking out, sometimes uncomfortably, teaching prevention for healthy and compassion for stricken; their message is one of abstinence, monogamy, protection, including condoms, and avoidance of drugs; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As a nurse holds the hands and head of one of the seven surviving octuplets born in Houston in December, a doctor peers at the back of the eyes through an ophthalmosocope. In assembly line fashion, the eye doctor examines each child. The aim is to seek the earliest sign of a condition known as retinopathy of prematurity, resulting from abnormal blood vessel growth, and to use a laser to prevent a detached retina, which can cause blindness. The octuplets were born nearly four months before the mother's due date of April 1. Like other infants born many weeks too early, they are at high risk of developing retinopathy in both eyes.

headline.main: Staving Off Blindness in the Tiniest of Infants

docs.abstract: Infants born many weeks premature run high risk of developing potentially blinding eye condition known as retinopathy of prematurity; at least 55,000 babies born prematurely each year are at highest risk, and about 1,000 of them suffer severe visual impairment or blindness from the condition; figures would be much higher if pediatric ophthalmologists did not use lasers or freezing technique to try to limit damage; diagrams (M)
